employee_compensation_insurance.title: What is Employee’s Compensation Insurance?
description: Every company must ensure a safe workplace, but accidents can still happen. Injuries or, in severe cases, death during employment require compensation under laws like the Employee’s Compensation Act 1923 (previously called as the Workmen’s Compensation Act, 1923). Not compensating can lead to legal issues, affecting employee confidence and the business's reputation. Employee’s compensation insurance (commonly known as WC policy or WC insurance) helps financially, covering compensation and legal costs. It also protects against lawsuits, as employees usually give up the right to sue for workplace negligence when accepting benefits. Previously known as Workmen Compensation Insurance, it ensures both businesses and employees are financially protected. ICICI Lombard’s Employee’s Compensation Insurance helps you financially safeguard your employees and their families against unfortunate workplace accidents and mishaps. Most importantly, it presents you as a thoughtful and caring employer who values his workforce, an asset for any organization.

employee_compensation_act.title: What is the Employee’s Compensation Act?
employee_compensation_act.overview: A statutory law that ensures financial support to workers in case of accidents occurring during the course of employment.
coverage_conditions: Injury resulting in inability to continue work

compensation_details.compensation: Amount equal to 50% of the monthly wages of the deceased employee multiplied by the relevant factor OR An amount of Rs 1.2 lakhs, whichever is more
An amount equal to 60% of the monthly wages of the injured employee multiplied by the relevant factor. OR An amount of Rs 1.4 lakhs, whichever is more

compensation_details.scenario: Permanent partial disablement result from the injury
compensation_details.compensation: In the case of an injury specified in Part II of Schedule I, Percentage of the loss of earning capacity caused by that injury (I)in the case of an injury not specified in Schedule I, Proportionate to the loss of earning capacity as assessed by the qualified medical practitioner permanently caused by the injury ()

compensation_details.scenario: Temporary disablement whether total or partial results from the injury
compensation_details.compensation: A half monthly payment of the sum equivalent to 25% of monthly wages of the employee to be paid in accordance with the provisions of sub-section (2) section 4 of Employee’s Compensation Act, 1923.

coverage_details.titlee: What is Covered under Employee’s Compensation Insurance?
legal_liability_covered_under: The Employee’s Compensation Act, 1923 is a law that ensures financial support to workers in case of accidents that occur during the course of their employment. Whether the employee is working full-time, part-time, or on a casual basis, they are entitled to compensation under this Act. The provisions apply when an employee suffers injuries that make them unfit to continue their work or, in unfortunate cases, when the injury results in death.

Accident must not occur for personal benefit

employee_compensation_faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions – Employee’s Compensation Policy

items.question: What types of injuries or illnesses are typically excluded from coverage under Employee’s (Workmen’s) Compensation Insurance?
items.answer: For complete list of exclusions, read the policy wordings here.

items.question: How does the nature of employment or work-related tasks impact the exclusions under Employee’s (Worker’s) compensation insurance?
items.answer: Jobs involving high-risk activities like construction or firefighting may have different exclusions than office roles.

items.question: Are there any pre-existing health conditions that may be excluded from coverage under Employee’s (Workmen’s) Compensation Insurance?
items.answer: Pre-existing health conditions not directly caused by work activities can be excluded. Consult the insurer for details.

items.question: In what situations might an Employee’s (Workmen’s) compensation insurance claim be denied based on policy exclusions?
items.answer: Claims can be denied for non-fatal injuries with less than 3 days disablement, self-inflicted injuries, or injuries under influence of drugs/alcohol.

items.question: What are the basic coverage provided under Employee (Workmen’s) Compensation policy?
items.answer: The policy provides coverage for accidental death, permanent total disability, permanent partial disability, and temporary total disability.

items.question: What addon covers are provided in Employee’s (Workmen’s) Compensation policy?
items.answer: Occupational disease, contractor/sub-contractor coverage, and medical expenses.

items.question: What is Permanent Total Disablement?
items.answer: Permanent total disablement means incapacity to perform all work the employee was capable of at the time of accident.

items.question: What legal liabilities are covered in Employee’s compensation policy?
items.answer: Covers Employee’s Compensation Act, Fatal Accidents Act, and Common Laws.

items.question: How is Employee’s Compensation policy different from ESIC (Employee State Insurance)?
items.answer: WC/EC policy can cover construction workers, employees with wages above statutory ESIC limits, and seasonal factories unlike ESIC.

items.question: What is occupational disease cover?
items.answer: Occupational diseases specified under Schedule III of the Act are covered if directly caused by nature of occupation.

items.question: What is the purpose of Employee’s (Workmen’s) Compensation Insurance (earlier known as WC insurance)?
items.answer: It protects both employers and employees financially for workplace injuries or illnesses.
